awd_titl_txt: REU Site: AWaRE Advanced Wireless Research Experiences at the University of Notre Dame
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the Notre Dame University.  This REU Site will host a diverse group of undergraduate students who will spend their summer working on research on next generation wireless technologies.  Wireless communication is already ubiquitous and is moving rapidly towards fifth-generation mobile services to enable a broad range of wireless services which are fundamental to our everyday lives as well as to the development of new technologies.  This REU Site provides students with the opportunities to explore the challenges of next-generation wireless networks and to be involved in research that may impact the understanding and uses of the wireless communication spectrum over which wireless signals are transmitted. The research is led by the faculty of the Notre Dame Wireless Institute. Students will receive hands-on experience in the design, implementation, deployment, evaluation, and measurement of wireless technologies and mobile networks using state-of-the-art equipment and systems.  The site will provide mentoring and other professional development opportunities that should impact the future academic and professional careers of the students. The site plans to attract talented undergraduate students from across the nation, particularly focusing on recruiting students from groups traditionally under-represented in the computing fields.

The pillars of this REU Site involve collaboration between the Notre Dame Wireless Institute, the City of South Bend next-generation advanced wireless research platform, and Notre Dame's membership in the Broadband Wireless Access and Applications Industry-University Cooperative Research Center. The technical focus of the research is on experimental discoveries using facilities, a research environment, and expertise unique to the Wireless Institute.  A broad range of wireless research is targeted including millimeter-wave wireless, antennas and circuits, radar signal processing, turbomachinery sensors, full spectrum sensing with low-cost pervasive sensors, drone communications, crowd-source WiFi characterization, Bluetooth low energy ad-hoc networks for emergency responders, and manufacturing floor operational efficiency via wearable wireless devices.  The project has the potential to develop new technologies and expand the understanding of the wireless spectrum.

The AWaRE REU provides talented students with an opportunity to explore and study the challenges of next-generation wireless networks. The AWaRE REU program aims to expose undergraduate students to hands-on experience with experimental research on next-generation wireless technologies. Such research includes designing, implementing, deploying, evaluating, and measuring wireless technologies and mobile networks.

The students participate in ongoing research projects under the guidance of two PI’s, senior personnel (also faculty/research professors), and their graduate students. The participants have the opportunity to work with numerous types of state-of-the-art equipment and systems, thereby providing them with invaluable experience for their future academic and professional careers. The three objectives of the AWaRE REU program are: 

  1. Recruit a diverse group of undergraduates from across the country.
  2. Expose participants to the research life cycle.
  3. Help participants develop skills and knowledge to advance their careers as they transition to the workforce or graduate school. 

The following table provides the demographics of the AWaRE REU applicants and participants from 2018 thru 2021. The AWaRE REU program included participants from across the country, attracting them from Washington State to Massachusetts and several states in between. We had seven – first-time college students participate, 13 ethnic minorities, and five females.

The second goal of the AWaRE REU is to expose students to the research life cycle. Likewise, several students noted how this program made them more aware of real-world research; they learned what it means to do research, work independently, find information, and write applications. Students also commonly reported learning coding skills and STEM content such as machine learning, transistors, or wireless communication. At the end of the program, the participants present their research at a symposium. In addition, they share their poster and discuss their findings.

All faculty members reported that the program had a significant impact in making students more aware of graduate school options, expanding participants’ awareness of STEM career possibilities, and providing information and skills to help participants in their future careers.

The third goal of the AWaRE REU is to help participants develop skills and knowledge to advance their careers as they transition to the workforce or graduate school. The AWaRE REU participants reported that they learned about the research process, how to use software and coding programs, work on a research team, find information, write applications, and the importance of self-direction in research. More specifically, participants reported using software engineering practices (e.g., unit tests, documentation, software architecture), testing of software when working with hardware (e.g., using an oscilloscope, measurement equipment, network analyzer), coding in Python and C++, conducting Monte Carlo simulations, Web app development, Database designing, and debugging.

The AWaRE REU faculty provides opportunities for the participants to explore new research experiences, improve their technical skills, and expand their awareness of STEM career possibilities while providing a supportive research experience.
